author: By Bret Stephens
title: Meet a Secret Trump Voter
description: ‘Being a lesbian who’s voting for Trump is like coming out of the closet again.’
content: Chris is a registered Democrat in her 50s who lives in Manhattan. She’s well-educated, well-traveled and well-informed. She has voted for candidates of both parties over the years and was enthusiastic for Bernie Sanders in 2016.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marie Tae McDermott
title: What to Know About Voting by Mail in California
description: County election officials will soon begin mailing ballots to the state’s 21 million registered voters.
content: Good morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: Phil Klay’s New Novel Is a Sobering Look at America’s Wars
description: With a big cast of characters, “Missionaries” tells the story of Colombian narco gangs and the government and military agencies who persecute them.
content: War, like cancer, is a friend to the short story writer. It allows the heat under a life to be turned up quickly. In his first book, the story collection “Redeployment,” which won a National Book Award in 2014, Phil Klay dispensed that heat wisely. The book was about soldiers and veterans who served in the Iraq War, as Klay did. Those stories contained deep feeling but were nimble. They displayed an alacrity of mind and arrived like armored tanks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: New York City Ballet Dropped From a Woman’s Photo-Sharing Lawsuit
description: The suit cited the company, its school and dancers in a case that described “a fraternity-like atmosphere” at the ballet. Her ex-boyfriend remains a defendant.
content: Two years after a photo-sharing scandal involving explicit images rocked New York City Ballet, a judge has dismissed most of the legal claims made by the woman whose lawsuit started it all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hailey Fuchs
title: More judges order the Postal Service to suspend policies slowing the mail, citing risk to the election.
description: More judges are ordering the Postal Service to suspend its new policies slowing the mail, citing risks to the pandemic-era election.
content: Two federal judges ruled against the Postal Service in three separate cases, ordering temporary injunctions to force it to suspend changes to its operations that have contributed to widespread delays in the delivery of mail.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexander Burns
title: Kamala Harris is expected to address Judge Barrett’s nomination and the Supreme Court in North Carolina.
description: On a trip to North Carolina where she is expected to speak about Judge Amy Coney Barrett, Senator Kamala Harris will take a rare turn in the campaign spotlight today.
content: If political tradition is any guide — and in the Trump era, it might not be — the two presidential candidates may stay out of the spotlight on the eve of their first debate.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Elon Musk: ‘A.I. Doesn’t Need to Hate Us to Destroy Us’
description: In a conversation with Kara Swisher, the billionaire entrepreneur talks space-faring civilization, battery-powered everything and computer chips in your skull.
content: Elon Musk has a vision of the future, and — as one of the world’s richest men with four corporations under his reign — the means to try to manifest it. In a conversation with Kara Swisher, he outlines his theory of, well, everything.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: A Biden campaign video shows how small Trump’s $750 tax bill is, compared with what average workers pay.
description: Not long after The New York Times published an investigation into President Trump’s long-sought tax returns, the campaign of Joseph R. Biden Jr. turned one of its most revealing findings — that Mr. Trump paid only $750 in federal income taxes the year he won the presidency — into a 30-second video comparing that tax bill to those paid by American workers.
content: Not long after The New York Times published an investigation into President Trump’s long-sought tax returns, the campaign of Joseph R. Biden Jr. turned one of its most revealing findings — that Mr. Trump paid only $750 in federal income taxes the year he won the presidency — into a 30-second video comparing that tax bill to those paid by American workers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reed Abelson
title: Some Workers Face Looming Cutoffs in Health Insurance
description: Coverage is a major expense for employers, especially those in small businesses, as they deal with the pandemic’s economic fallout. Many may face end-of-year renewal deadlines that are harder and harder to afford.
content: Jeremy Fritz stopped working as an assistant manager for a fitness center in Carlsbad, Calif., during the pandemic lockdown in the spring when gyms were first closed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: Miami Heat Advance to the N.B.A. Finals
description: The Heat beat the Boston Celtics in the Eastern Conference finals on Sunday and will face the Los Angeles Lakers for the championship.
content: The Miami Heat are on their way to the N.B.A. finals, continuing one of the more improbable postseason runs in recent years. They beat the Boston Celtics on Sunday, 125-113, to win the Eastern Conference finals in six games.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Perri Klass, M.D
title: Back-to-School Season in Italy
description: There is a cultural emphasis on children being with other children, and having them go to school in person.
content: As an American pediatrician who has spent a lot of time in Italy, where the pandemic began in February and the whole country was in lockdown by early March, I’m interested in how children and families in Italy are responding to the current phase of reopening schools.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Put Down Your Pencils, but Not Your Mask: SATs in the Covid Era
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, September 28, 2020.
content: “It’s hard for me to trust that two people’s applications will be weighed the same if one of them has a test score and the other doesn’t.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sameer Yasir
title: Swami Agnivesh, Crusader Against Labor Abuses in India, Dies at 80
description: A pacifist monk, he championed social justice causes, fighting against child labor, indentured servitude and a rising tide of Hindu fundamentalism.
content: Swami Agnivesh, a revered longtime campaigner against child labor and indentured servitude in India, died on Sept. 11 in New Delhi. He was 80.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eliza Shapiro and James Estrin
title: Masks, Floor Decals, Mute Buttons: How Schools Are Scrambling to Open
description: Most students who have chosen in-person learning will be returning to classrooms this week. Teachers and principals are racing to be ready for them.
content: Nine students will sit at desks six feet apart in classrooms that used to hold 30 children. Gyms, cafeterias and auditoriums will be largely off-limits. And, if all goes according to plan, students and staff will not see each other in-person without their masks on for many months to come.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Poniewozik
title: Donald Trump Was the Real Winner of ‘The Apprentice’
description: The reality show temporarily revived his business fortunes by creating the illusion that he was already doing great.
content: Donald J. Trump’s greatest success as a businessman, it turns out, was playing one on TV.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allyson Waller
title: Brain-Eating Amoeba Found in Lake Jackson, Texas, Water Supply
description: A 6-year-old boy died in the Gulf Coast community after being infected by an organism that enters the nose and travels to the brain.
content: The governor of Texas issued a disaster declaration on Sunday for a Gulf Coast county where a 6-year-old boy died after being infected by a brain-eating amoeba and the organism was found in the water supply.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi
title: Bipartisan House Bill Aims to Fix Boeing 737 Max Safety Lapses
description: The measure seeks to strengthen the Federal Aviation Administration and impose tougher penalties on corporate executives who undermine regulators.
content: The top Democrat and Republican on the House’s transportation committee unveiled a bill on Monday aimed at addressing some of the problems that contributed to two fatal crashes of Boeing’s 737 Max jet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Velsey
title: Coronavirus Brings a Medical Resident to the Bronx
description: She put her career on hold to raise a family, but the pandemic gave her a chance to become a doctor.
content: While it’s common to approach a New York apartment hunt with a long wish list, Taruna Chandok had just one requirement for her first apartment in the city: “The only criterion was near the hospital,” said Dr. Chandok, 45, who started a residency in internal medicine at the BronxCare Hospital Center in July.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei and Maggie Haberman
title: Brad Parscale, an ex-campaign manager for Trump, was hospitalized after the police were called to his home.
description: MIAMI — President Trump’s former campaign manager, Brad Parscale, was hospitalized after the police were called to his home in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., by his wife, who said he had guns and was threatening to hurt himself, officials said on Sunday evening.
content: MIAMI — President Trump’s former campaign manager, Brad Parscale, was hospitalized after the police were called to his home in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., by his wife, who said he had guns and was threatening to hurt himself, officials said on Sunday evening.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: The Picture of a Broken Tax System
description: Donald Trump’s tax returns illustrate the profound inequities of the tax code and the shambolic state of federal enforcement.
content: In the years before he became president, Donald Trump lived lavishly while paying little in federal income taxes. The Times reported on Sunday that Mr. Trump paid no taxes in 10 of the 15 years immediately preceding his run for the White House. In each of the following two years, 2016 and 2017, he paid the token sum of $750.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard C. Paddock
title: American Could Face Prison in Thailand After Posting Negative Reviews of a Resort
description: The man was arrested under Thailand’s criminal defamation law, which has been used to silence critics and stifle dissent. The hotel that brought charges acknowledges that using the law might be “excessive.”
content: An American man who lives in Thailand was unhappy that a resort hotel  wanted to charge him a $15 corkage fee for bringing his own bottle of gin to the restaurant. He argued with a manager and then later did what has become second nature for disgruntled tourists: He posted negative reviews of the resort online.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Cohn
title: If Race Comes Down to Omaha, Poll Shows Biden Has an Edge
description: Nebraska’s Second Congressional District could play a decisive role in a very close election.
content: In a close race, the presidential election could be decided by an unlikely spot: Nebraska’s Second Congressional District, including Omaha and most of its suburbs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Trump’s Taxes
description: And what else you need to know today.
content: Even though taxes on wealthy Americans have fallen sharply in recent decades, most still pay a lot to the federal government. A typical billionaire pays tens of millions of dollars in federal income taxes each year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: The Trump Tax Bombshell
description: A Times report unravels much of the mystery: This is your morning tip sheet.
content: It looks as if the president paid $750 in taxes in both 2016 and 2017 — and for him, those were generous years. It’s Monday, and this is your politics tip sheet. Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Salman Masood
title: Ex-President of Pakistan Is Indicted on Money Laundering Charges
description: The case against Asif Ali Zardari, widower of former Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto, is the latest in a string of moves against opposition figures that his supporters say are politically motivated.
content: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — A former president of Pakistan, Asif Ali Zardari, was indicted on Monday in a money laundering case, the latest legal action against him and one that his supporters say is part of a wider trend against politicians opposed to Prime Minister Imran Khan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sydney Ember and Astead W. Herndon
title: End the Filibuster? Pack the Court? The Left Is Pushing Biden
description: A party that is increasingly seeking to play by different rules is led by a figure who helped create the current ones. The outcome of the fight will help define the Democratic Party going forward.
content: There is a battle brewing among Washington Democrats that is set to boil over if Democrats take back the Senate and former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. defeats President Trump in November.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Messman
title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Saturday Night Live’ and the First Presidential Debate
description: Chris Rock hosts the return of “Saturday Night Live,” President Trump and Joe Biden face off in their first debate and Jimmy Stewart and Jean Arthur star in the classic Frank Capra film “You Can’t Take It With You.”
content: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, Sept. 28-Oct. 4. Dates, details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danielle Braff
title: The New Helicopter Parents Are on Zoom
description: With kids needing so much help in remote learning, we may be pushed to become the parents we never wanted to be.
content: On the first day of remote learning, my daughter was nervous she’d press the wrong button. So I pulled up a chair next to her bedroom desk and she and I began third grade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: After dismissing an investigation into his taxes as ‘fake news,’ Trump lashes out at the suggestion that he is not as wealthy as he claims.
description: President Trump shifted his position overnight on a sweeping New York Times investigative report on his taxes, accusing the paper on Monday of using “illegally obtained information” after initially saying on Sunday that the article was “totally fake news.”
content: President Trump shifted his position overnight on a sweeping New York Times investigative report on his taxes, accusing the paper on Monday of using “illegally obtained information” after initially saying on Sunday that the article was “totally fake news.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: How Corey Johnson’s Decision to Drop Out Changed the N.Y.C. Mayor’s Race
description: The pandemic and the George Floyd protests have altered the 2021 contest, and new candidates are emerging.
content: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]
source.name: The New York Times

title: Trump will talk about the coronavirus today, and Harris speaks in North Carolina.
description: Here are the daily schedules of the presidential and vice-presidential candidates for Monday, Sept. 28. All times are Eastern time.
content: Here are the daily schedules of the presidential and vice-presidential candidates for Monday, Sept. 28. All times are Eastern time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane E. Brody
title: The Underused Weight Loss Option: Bariatric Surgery
description: Experts say it can result in long-term weight loss and significantly improve physical and emotional health and even longevity.
content: Growing rates of obesity among Americans are clear evidence that even the best intentions and strongest motivations are often not enough to help seriously overweight people lose a significant amount of weight and, more important, keep it off.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum
title: How the Biden-Trump Debate Will Play on TV (Don’t Expect Fact-Checks)
description: “My job is to be as invisible as possible,” said Chris Wallace of Fox News, the moderator of the opening matchup on Tuesday.
content: [Follow our live updates on Trump vs Biden in the 2020 Election.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Graham
title: For Conservative Christian Women, Amy Coney Barrett’s Success Is Personal
description: Judge Barrett is a new kind of icon for some, one they have not seen before in American cultural and political life.
content: Ruth Malhotra had just arrived in Florida for a vacation with some girlfriends from high school and their families when President Trump was scheduled to introduce his next nominee for the Supreme Court on Saturday afternoon. A college football game was on the television at their rented beach house. “Turn off football and turn on C-SPAN!” she told her friends. “We’ve got to watch this; this is historic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Cohn
title: A single congressional district in Nebraska could prove decisive in a close presidential election.
description: In a close race, the presidential election could be decided by an unlikely spot: Nebraska’s Second Congressional District, which includes Omaha and most of its suburbs.
content: In a close race, the presidential election could be decided by an unlikely spot: Nebraska’s Second Congressional District, which includes Omaha and most of its suburbs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dylan Loeb McClain
title: Arthur Ashkin, 98, Dies; Nobel Laureate Invented a ‘Tractor Beam’
description: It isn’t quite “Star Trek,” but his optical tweezers use the pressure of light in a laser beam to seize and manipulate microscopic objects, from atoms to living cells.
content: Arthur Ashkin, a physicist who was awarded a 2018 Nobel Prize for figuring out how to harness the power of light to trap microscopic objects for closer study, calling his invention optical tweezers, died on Sept. 21 at his home in Rumson, N.J. He was 98.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Power and Influence of Mitch McConnell
description: “Mr. McConnell has proved to be a far greater threat to our democracy than Donald Trump,” a reader says. Also: New York City schools’ reopening.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Kim
title: A Spread Worthy of Royalty
description: Banchan, the small dishes that often accompany a Korean meal, should be treasured in their own right.
content: In Min Jin Lee’s 2017 novel “Pachinko,” a restaurant owner approaches the protagonist, Sunja, after hearing of her famous kimchi. Sunja’s reputation preceding her, the owner hires her on the spot to supply his restaurant’s banchan — the small side dishes that often accompany a Korean meal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Hoffman
title: What We Learned From Week 3 of the N.F.L. Season
description: Fourth quarter leads were far from safe in a week where Green Bay, Buffalo, Pittsburgh, Tennessee, Seattle and Chicago — yes, the Bears — improved to 3-0.
content: No lead was safe on Sunday, with several teams engineering huge second-half comebacks (yes, the Falcons collapsed again). There was a little of everything — there was even a tie! — and a week that was expected to be an appetizer for Monday night’s matchup between Kansas City and Baltimore proved to have plenty of its own entertainment value.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Lyall
title: Engage or Proceed? Debating Trump, the Unpredictable Aggressor
description: Joe Biden has the scouting report of the president’s past debates and four years in office. One way to use it? Respond to unpredictability with a simple, “Here’s my stability plan.”
content: Hillary Clinton was attempting to talk about health care in the second presidential debate in 2016 when her opponent, Donald J. Trump, suddenly moved across the stage and lurked behind her, in the manner of Snoopy pretending to be a vulture in the Peanuts cartoons. She could feel him breathing down her neck.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benedict Carey
title: A Theory About Conspiracy Theories
description: In a new study, psychologists tried to get a handle on the personality types that might be prone to outlandish beliefs.
content: More than 1 in 3 Americans believe that the Chinese government engineered the coronavirus as a weapon, and another third are convinced that the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has exaggerated the threat of Covid-19 to undermine President Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Tobias
title: ‘Fargo’ Season 4 Premiere Recap: A History of Violence
description: The new season, starring Chris Rock and Jason Schwartzman, moves to the criminal underworld of Kansas City in 1950, a furnace in which American identity is forged.
content: “If America is a nation of immigrants, how does one become American?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurt Streeter
title: Hockey Needs Viewers. It Should Not Glorify Pain and Violence to Get Them.
description: A promotional video posted by the N.H.L. that glorified pain showed a disturbing embrace of violence by the league. The post has since been deleted.
content: The tortured relationship between pain, violence and sports burst sharply into view once again this month. The reminder came courtesy of a pair of reliable standard-bearers: professional hockey and football, both brimming with beauty and drama obscuring a dark side that should not be ignored.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei and Maggie Haberman
title: Brad Parscale, Ex-Campaign Manager for Trump, Is Hospitalized in Florida
description: The Fort Lauderdale police said that Mr. Parscale’s wife called the authorities to their home because he was armed and threatening to hurt himself.
content: MIAMI — President Trump’s former campaign manager, Brad Parscale, was hospitalized after the police were called to his home in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., by his wife, who said he had guns and was threatening to hurt himself, officials said on Sunday evening.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley and Luis Ferré-Sadurní
title: Warnings Issued as Virus Cases Rise in New York
description: Clusters of cases have emerged in Brooklyn and New York City’s northern suburbs in areas with large Orthodox Jewish communities.
content: After months of promising signs in its fight against the coronavirus, New York reported a spike in its rate of new cases on Monday, including a rise in New York City and in its northern suburbs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Concepción de León
title: Maryland Man Sentenced to a Year in Jail for Violating Ban on Large Parties
description: Shawn Marshall Myers was arrested in March, after prosecutors said he threw two parties of 50 or more people at his home in defiance of the state’s ban on gatherings of more than 10 people.
content: A Maryland man has been sentenced to one year in jail and fined $5,000 for throwing two large parties in violation of the state’s ban on gatherings of more than 10 people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: Fighting Between Armenia and Azerbaijan Risks Drawing in Bigger Powers
description: Escalation on both sides suggests that an extended conflict may ensue in Nagorno-Karabakh, increasing the possibility of involvement by countries like Russia and Turkey.
content: MOSCOW — A long-simmering territorial dispute in the Caucasus region that reignited in recent days, with tanks, artillery helicopters and infantry engaged in combat, suggests that the two sides — Azerbaijan and Armenia — are girding for an extended conflict rather than the border skirmishes that they have engaged in over the years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: China’s vaccines, Trump’s taxes, Zardari: Here’s what you need to know.
content: Chinese officials have begun to inoculate thousands of people with unproven coronavirus vaccines. Global health experts are bewildered: No other country has injected people outside the usual drug trial process to such a huge scale.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nagourney
title: The Reality TV Host vs. the Velvet Shiv: Trump and Biden in Debates
description: Joe Biden and Donald Trump will bring very different histories and styles to their presidential debate on Tuesday.
content: Donald J. Trump barely paused to thank his debate hosts before going on the attack after he took the stage at Hofstra University in September 2016. “Our jobs are fleeing the country,” he said grimly. “They’re going to Mexico.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Siobhan Burke
title: Review: In This Dance, Death Is Out in the Open
description: Eiko Otake’s performance at Green-Wood Cemetery in Brooklyn honored the ghosts in our midst.
content: Over the past couple of months in New York City, some dance artists have braved the process of presenting live performance outdoors. Like most social rituals these days, going to a show, even in the open air, involves a whole new set of behaviors. As you choose where to sit, you try not to encroach on anyone’s six-foot radius. You do your best to make small talk through masks, reading facial expressions from the bridge of the nose up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word + Quiz: arcane
description: This word has appeared in 122 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sandra E. Garcia
title: Tanqueray, Humans of New York Star, Brings in Over $1.5 Million in Donations
description: Stephanie Johnson, 76, returned to the blog to share stories from her incredible life, this time for a cause.
content: Last November, the internet fell in love with Tanqueray, a straight-shooting New Yorker who shared memories of her life as a burlesque dancer in the 1960s and ’70s with the many millions of people who follow Humans of New York on Instagram, Facebook, Twitter and Tumblr.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Griffith
title: Apple and Epic Games Spar Over Returning Fortnite to the App Store
description: The two companies argued in federal court over Apple’s power over apps, as their fight heads to trial next year.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — Apple and Epic Games, the maker of Fortnite, sparred in federal court on Monday over whether to reinstate the popular game in Apple’s App Store, raising antitrust arguments that may reshape a key part of the internet economy and the way people use smartphones.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: Gómez and Korda in French Open Decades After Their Fathers Played It, Too
description: Emilio Gómez won his way into the tournament 30 years after his father, Andrés, won the men’s singles title there.
content: Tennis remains a family game, and former French Open champion Andrés Gómez’s five children all became good enough to play college tennis in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine J. Wu
title: Trump Announces Plan to Ship 150 Million Rapid Coronavirus Tests
description: Governors of both parties welcomed the plan, but some health experts noted limitations of the kits made by Abbott Laboratories.
content: President Trump at the White House on Monday announced a plan to distribute 150 million rapid coronavirus tests purchased by the federal government to states, tribes and other jurisdictions in the coming months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: Can Amazon Conquer the World?
description: And what might we gain and lose from that?
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: Jackson-Mahomes III:‘The Whole WorldIs Watching’
description: They’re under 26, have won M.V.P.s and they can seemingly do anything. On Monday night, the N.F.L. gets a boost from the latest installment of its best current rivalry.
content: Elway-Montana. Aikman-Favre. Brady-Manning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Oster
title: What Parents Need to Know About School Coronavirus Case Data
description: Some reported cases come from districts that are operating fully remotely, or districts in which the cases occurred before school was open.
content: It is the start of a school year unlike any other. Many schools, especially in large urban districts, are fully remote. In New York, school opening was announced and then delayed. Some schools have opened and then grappled with quarantine. Others started closed and are now opening.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Taylor Swift’s ‘Folklore’ Returns to No. 1 for a Seventh Week
description: Propelled by full-album sales, the singer and songwriter’s surprise LP moved 87,000 copies, nearly double its haul from the week before.
content: A good rule of thumb for the 21st-century music business: Never count Taylor Swift out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Trump’s Debt, His Future and Ours
description: The president — our chief law enforcement and national security official — could be facing huge liabilities. That’s chilling.
content: The bombshell New York Times report on Donald Trump’s tax returns is a remarkable feat of journalism. The team deserves special praise for making their findings comprehensible to general readers, and not getting lost in the details.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Arango, Johnny Diaz and Carly Stern
title: 3 Killed in Fresh Wildfires in Northern California
description: In addition to the deaths, the famous Chateau Boswell winery is gone, a community of tiny homes for homeless people has burned, and an untold number of houses are feared lost.
content: LOS ANGELES — California’s famed wine country, already suffering an economic blow brought on by the coronavirus pandemic and covered in smoke for weeks, is on fire again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brad Lefton
title: The Best 60-Game Stretch in a Century Still Belongs to Ichiro Suzuki
description: No one managed to hit .400 this year despite excited speculation about the possibility in a truncated season, underscoring how impressive Suzuki’s late-season stretch in 2004 was.
content: After Charlie Blackmon of the Colorado Rockies completed a stretch of six consecutive multiple-hit games in August, his batting average ballooned to an even .500 after 17 games. Nolan Arenado marveled at his teammate’s otherworldliness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Shannon and Judith Levitt
title: Trump’s Taxes, Presidential Debate, Virus Deaths: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: The Supreme Court Ad Wars Begin
description: It didn’t take long for the fight over Judge Amy Coney Barrett to reach the airwaves, in races up and down the ballot.
content: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. I’m Nick Corasaniti. Lisa is off today, so I’m taking over and bringing my normal Tuesday coverage of all things media and messaging today instead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: The figure $750 could stick in voters’ minds after a Times report on Trump’s taxes.
description: The $750 that President Trump paid in federal income tax in 2016 and 2017, revealed on Sunday in a New York Times report, could stick in voters’ minds.
content: There was one very simple takeaway from a complicated New York Times exposé analyzing two decades of the president’s tax return data: $750.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: At the French Open, Cold Weather and a Ball That Will Not Behave
description: Paris in the fall is far different than Paris in the spring. The damp chill is forcing more changes than just the clothing.
content: It’s an old story. A venture to Paris filled with hopes for sun and blue skies. Instead, the air is cold and blustery, the skies are gray and there is some rain, too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine J. Wu
title: Black Microbiologists Push for Visibility Amid a Pandemic
description: A week of talks, panels and discussions seeks to counter an impression “that this talent pool just does not exist.”
content: A few days before her fifth-grade science fair, Ariangela Kozik awoke to the overwhelming scent of poultry past its due. It was exactly what the young scientist had been hoping for.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: Trump tries to improve his environmental record with a new water rule, but experts reject its efficacy.
description: The Environmental Protection Agency is preparing to overhaul the way communities test their water for lead, a policy change that will be pitched ahead of Election Day as a major environmental achievement for a president not noted for his conservation record.
content: The Environmental Protection Agency is preparing to overhaul the way communities test their water for lead, a policy change that will be pitched ahead of Election Day as a major environmental achievement for a president not noted for his conservation record.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: Doc Rivers Is Out as Los Angeles Clippers Coach
description: The Clippers were expected to contend for a championship this season, but they were upset in the second round of the playoffs as their big-name stars struggled.
content: After a disappointing playoff run for the Los Angeles Clippers, Doc Rivers is no longer the head coach of the team, he said Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Proulx
title: Civil Conversation Challenge for Teenagers, Forum 5: Voting and Democracy
description: How concerned do you think we should we be about the integrity of the 2020 election? What problems worry you most? What should be done to address them?
content: From Sept. 22 to Sept. 28, our Student Opinion column will be devoted to the issues we’ll be discussing in our Civil Conversation Challenge, but, as always, any teenager is invited to respond. We hope you’ll not only post your own thoughts, but also reply to the comments of others.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Past, Present and Future of Amy Coney Barrett
description: The judge’s nomination to the Supreme Court has enthused conservatives. What does her record say about the role she might play as a justice?
content: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Even as Americans Grew Richer, Inequality Persisted
description: A Federal Reserve survey of family finances shows that inequality was high last year. It’s likely to worsen because of the pandemic.
content: American families shored up their savings substantially between 2016 and 2019, according to Federal Reserve data released on Monday, but wealth inequality remained stubbornly high — and that was before the coronavirus pandemic took hold.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden
title: In France, Southerners Grumble at Virus Restrictions From Up North
description: People are irate after the government ordered restaurants and bars closed in Marseille and Aix-en-Provence, the only two cities in mainland France to face such measures.
content: PARIS — The longstanding antagonism that pits Paris, the occasionally overbearing French capital, against Marseille, its sunnier, more rambunctious rival on the Mediterranean coast, has found a new battleground: the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacob Bernstein
title: Harry Evans, Potentate of Print, Was Also a Social Butterfly
description: He and his wife Tina Brown hosted and attended some of New York’s most memorable gatherings. (Back when we gathered.)
content: One of Harry Evans’s gifts as a journalist was his understanding of power: who had it, why they got it, and — most significantly — how they misused it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher
title: China’s Economy Comes Roaring Back, Led by Wealthy Consumers
description: Big crowds at places like the Beijing auto show are a sign of good news, but China needs its less affluent to spend more before its growth engine can return to full speed.
content: BEIJING — Right before executives and car enthusiasts could gather in Geneva for the big auto show there in early March, the organizers called it off. As the coronavirus spread, other shows followed suit: Detroit, Los Angeles, New York, Paris and São Paulo.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Rothenberg
title: With No Last-Set Tiebreaker, French Open Match Lasts More Than Six Hours
description: Lorenzo Giustino defeated Corentin Moutet in a match that helped push the French Open slate to a post-midnight completion.
content: At the only Grand Slam tournament where marathon matches are still allowed to drift endlessly into the unknown, Lorenzo Giustino and Corentin Moutet took more than six hours to finish Monday what had started a day earlier at the French Open.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anahad O'Connor
title: A Potential Downside of Intermittent Fasting
description: A rigorous three-month study found that people lost little weight, and much of that may have been from muscle.
content: Intermittent fasting is a trendy weight loss strategy. But a new study found that a popular form of intermittent fasting called time-restricted eating produced minimal weight loss and one potential downside: muscle loss.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sandra E. Garcia
title: Seeing Ourselves in Bloom
description: Cristina Martinez makes paintings for hyphenated American life.
content: Cristina Martinez paints women as if they are flowers. In her brightly hued renderings, their heads loom and droop over their bodies, like blooms too heavy for their stems. Often, they are dressed in vibrant gowns with flecks of paint to mimic sequins; the color of their skin, a moist terra cotta, similar in shades to the Black and brown women who raised the artist.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Caramanica
title: A Teenage Producer With a TikTok Hit Brings New Zealand to the World
description: Jawsh 685’s “Savage Love” became a global pop smash. Next up: graduating from high school and, hopefully, getting on a plane.
content: During the early months of pandemic isolation, there were few distractions as cathartic and cheering as the Culture Dance challenge on TikTok, set to the squelchy, loping “Laxed (Siren Beat),” by Jawsh 685. The choreography that became associated with it was, by TikTok standards, elementary — a casual semaphore of joy with a mild wiggle of the waist. Almost anyone could participate, and participate they did.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Schuessler
title: Amid the Monument Wars, a Rally for ‘More History’
description: Historians recently gathered at Civil War sites across the country in an effort to highlight distortions, omissions and the erasure of Black contributions.
content: On Saturday, a group of about 30 mustered under drizzly skies at the edge of the battlefield at Gettysburg, Pa. The site of one of the bloodiest and most important battles of the Civil War, Gettysburg has seen its share of clashes over the memory of the war in recent years. But this group was there to make a stand of a different kind.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $1 Million
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Roose
title: How ‘Save the Children’ Is Keeping QAnon Alive
description: Appropriating anti-trafficking narratives is helping the pro-Trump conspiracy theory fuel its community’s hunger for vengeance.
content: Last year, QAnon was on the ropes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: The Coronavirus Mostly Spares Younger Children. Teens Aren’t So Lucky.
description: Younger children are about half as likely as older teenagers and adults to become infected, new studies suggest.
content: Teenagers are about twice as likely to become infected with the coronavirus as younger children, according to an analysis released Monday by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justin French and Haidee Findlay-Levin
title: As Temperatures Drop, Elegant and Monochromatic Looks Emerge
description: Outerwear and suiting that hew to a palette of charcoals, blacks and moody blues.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘Kids Need Superheroes Now More Than Ever’
description: In this lesson, students will learn why one author believes that comic book heroes can help children get through these difficult times. Then, they will create their own superhero to help us cope.
content: Featured Article: “Kids Need Superheroes Now More Than Ever” by Megan Margulies
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Asimov
title: How to Read a Wine Label, in 12 Easy Lessons
description: The wine shop can be intimidating, with so many different styles of labeling. Here’s help in decoding a dozen basic types.
content: Buying wine can be a paralyzing challenge. Facing a wall of unfamiliar bottles can frustrate even the most worldly consumer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Branch
title: Cal Athletic Director: Football Will Help School Balance Sports Budget
description: California has been considering how to adjust with a $55 million budget shortfall. An influx of TV money by staging a football season will help.
content: When the Pac-12 Conference announced last week that it would squeeze in a football season this fall, following other top leagues and overturning its own decision from August to wait until 2021, the responses were predictable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Trump Denounces Anti-Catholic Bias Even as He Attacks Biden’s Faith
description: President Trump has accused Joe Biden, a Catholic, of being “against God” and “against the Bible.” Of Judge Amy Coney Barrett, he has claimed about Democrats, “They’re going after her Catholicism.”
content: WASHINGTON — President Trump has accused his opponent, former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., of being “against God,” “against the Bible” and “essentially against religion.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nancy Hass and Guido Taroni
title: A Colorful Homecoming for a Milanese Designer
description: After living around the world, Nicolò Castellini Baldissera has returned to the city in which his family — and his heart — has always resided.
content: OF ALL OF ITALY’S big cities, Milan seems the least like a cozy hometown. Rome’s ancient ruins and joie de vivre make it warmly livable, and Venice’s canals evoke intimacy and romance, but Milan is all business. After being largely destroyed in the bombings of World War II, it was rebuilt in the decades that followed as the fast-paced, often unlovely center of the fashion and design industries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: The Good, the Bad and the Ugly, Meet Donald Trump
description: Over the past five days, we learned a lot about the president and his powers.
content: Bret Stephens: Gail, I feel like we’re living in a sci-fi movie, on a dying planet, getting bombarded by at least one giant asteroid a day. Let’s take them one at a time: The Times’s latest scoop on President Trump’s tax returns. On one hand, I’m appalled. On the other, not shocked in the slightest. I mean, it’s not exactly news that Trump’s businesses have usually lost money hand over fist. Your thoughts?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein
title: ‘We’re at War’: New York City Faces a Financial Abyss
description: The pandemic has crippled tourism, retail and the culture sector. The damage could last years, and layoffs, service cuts and added debt are all on the table.
content: The unemployment rate in New York City is 16 percent, twice as high as the rest of the country. Personal income tax revenue is expected to drop by $2 billion this fiscal year. Only a third of hotel rooms are occupied, and apartment vacancies in Manhattan have hit a peak.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Egan
title: 7 Takeaways From Mariah Carey’s Memoir
description: In “The Meaning of Mariah Carey,” the singer and songwriter opens up about abuse, infidelity, racism, Derek Jeter and much more.
content: “I cried on my 18th birthday. I thought I was a failure because I didn’t have a record deal yet,” Mariah Carey writes in her memoir, “The Meaning of Mariah Carey,” which comes out on Tuesday. Now 50, the singer and songwriter has recorded 15 studio albums, including more No. 1 singles than any other solo artist. Here is what she tells readers in her new book.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: Head of Auschwitz Memorial Seeks Easing of Nigerian Boy’s Prison Sentence
description: “I cannot remain indifferent,” the director wrote in a letter to Nigeria’s president about a 13-year-old who was sentenced to 10 years’ imprisonment and menial labor on a blasphemy charge.
content: The director of the Auschwitz-Birkenau museum in Poland has asked Nigeria’s president to pardon a teenager who was sentenced to 10 years’ imprisonment with menial labor over a blasphemy conviction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: Derek Jeter Is Back in the Postseason With a Whole New Perspective
description: Jeter played 158 playoff games as a Yankee. This week, he’ll experience his first as the Marlins’ chief executive: “It’s completely different, because you have no control whatsoever.”
content: The chief executive of the Miami Marlins has the most postseason experience of anyone in baseball history. For Derek Jeter, all of it came in his first act, as shortstop for the Yankees — 158 games in the caldron of the playoffs and World Series.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Watch Paris Fashion Week Now
description: Watch along with us.
content: Paris Fashion Week runs from Sept. 28 through Oct. 6. We’ll see Christian Dior and Kenzo, Thebe Magugu Maison Margiela. We’ll be providing shows right here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Kaplan and Neil Vigdor
title: Kamala Harris says appointing Amy Coney Barrett to the Supreme Court would imperil health care and abortion rights.
description: Senator Kamala Harris warns of far-reaching consequences to American society if Judge Amy Coney Barrett is confirmed to the Supreme Court.
content: Senator Kamala Harris warned on Monday of far-reaching consequences to American society if Judge Amy Coney Barrett is confirmed to the Supreme Court, saying that the health coverage and abortion rights were in peril.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shoshana Kordova
title: Sometimes It’s Not Just Shyness
description: Selective mutism is a common anxiety condition whereby kids who are normally chatty at home clam up around outsiders or at school.
content: When my youngest daughter was 3, her preschool teacher called me a few months into the school year to tell me she still had no idea what my daughter’s voice sounded like.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Are the Bears That Good or Are the Falcons That Bad?
description: The Chicago Bears started the season with a 3-0 record and a quarterback controversy. The Atlanta Falcons (0-3) have personnel stability and a penchant for blowing leads.
content: Bears 30, Falcons 26. If you didn’t closely follow the N.F.L. weekend action, you might guess it was a decent game, closely contested. But hidden beneath the score was a most unlikely game, played by two teams whose fortunes are now on drastically different trajectories.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Hong
title: Clare Bronfman, Facing Sentencing, Refuses to Disavow ‘Sex Cult’ Leader
description: Ms. Bronfman will be the first defendant in the Nxivm case to be sentenced. Prosecutors have asked for five years in prison.
content: For more than a decade, Clare Bronfman, an heiress to the Seagram liquor fortune, devoted her life to supporting a self-help group called Nxivm. She quit her equestrian career, moved to Nxivm’s headquarters in upstate New York and poured millions of dollars into the group.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley and Sara Creta
title: The Ship That Stopped 7,000 Migrants, and Smuggled 700,000 Cigarettes
description: The Caprera, an Italian warship, was deployed to Tripoli to help combat people-smugglers in Libya. Some of its sailors gathered a cargo of contraband.
content: BRINDISI, Italy — By the time the Caprera, a small gray Italian warship, returned to its base in southern Italy in July 2018, it had helped intercept more than 80 migrant smuggling boats off the coast of Libya, and stopped more than 7,000 people from reaching Europe.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: Sept. 28, 2020
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Sept. 28, 2020.
content: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Sept. 28, 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: Now Pitching for the Yankees … These 13 Guys
description: A quirk in Major League Baseball’s modified postseason format could lead to an unusual assortment of pitchers getting innings aside from the usual starters and relievers.
content: CLEVELAND — En route to their World Series title last season, the Washington Nationals did something quite simple and fairly common during the baseball postseason: they used their best handful of pitchers, regardless of their regular-season role, as often as possible.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeff Asher
title: Murders Are Rising. Blaming a Party Doesn’t Add Up.
description: The data reveals a different picture than the party-driven explanation President Trump and the Department of Justice have offered.
content: Violent crime is expected to be addressed during the first presidential debate Tuesday, and President Trump has long attacked “Democrat cities” for not doing enough to stop it. In the run-up to the 2018 midterms, he called Democrats the “party of crime.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Mervosh
title: ‘It’s Not in My Head’: They Survived the Coronavirus, but They Never Got Well
description: With seven million known cases of the coronavirus across the country, more people are suffering from symptoms that go on and on.
content: They caught the coronavirus months ago and survived it, but they are still stuck at home, gasping for breath. They are no longer contagious, but some feel so ill that they can barely walk around the block, and others grow dizzy trying to cook dinner. Month after month, they rush to the hospital with new symptoms, pleading with doctors for answers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Otis
title: A Sports Columnist Who Has Been in the Game
description: Kurt Streeter, who writes Sports of The Times, played pro tennis before turning to journalism. As a writer, he’s drawn to people “who struggle and try to bounce back.”
content: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heather Murphy
title: $20 Million Settlement Reached in Officer’s Fatal Shooting of Handcuffed Man
description: Michael Owen, a police corporal in Prince George’s County, Md., shot William H. Green six times while he was in a patrol car in January, the authorities said.
content: A Maryland county has reached a $20 million settlement with the family of an unarmed Black man who was fatally shot by a police corporal while he was handcuffed in a patrol car in January, officials said on Monday. The figure, announced on Sunday, makes it among the largest settlements in a case involving a killing by a police officer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daisuke Wakabayashi
title: Google Demands 30% Cut From App Developers in Its Play Store
description: Some companies like Netflix and Spotify had avoided making the payment when people paid for something inside their apps.
content: OAKLAND, Calif. — Google said it would no longer allow any apps to circumvent its payment system within the Google Play store that provides the company a cut of in-app purchases.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Will Pop Music of the Future Rely on Actual Musicians, or Avatars?
description: The pandemic has sped up how digital look-alikes are reshaping stardom.
content: The pandemic has upended how musicians interact with their fans in unprecedented fashion. There is no more gathering — in person, at least. So in coordination with technology companies, artists have been trying new things: a Travis Scott concert in Fortnite, a 100 gecs show in Minecraft, a virtual gig by the Weeknd on TikTok.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Grullón Paz
title: What you need to know about the upcoming presidential debates.
description: Like many things this year, the presidential and vice-presidential debates will look a little different. There will only be one moderator per debate, and we’re still not sure if there will be a crowd — and, if there is, how many people will be allowed in. Each debate will start at 9 p.m. Eastern time and will run uninterrupted for an hour and a half, according to the Commission on Presidential Debates.
content: Like many things this year, the presidential and vice-presidential debates will look a little different. There will only be one moderator per debate, and we’re still not sure if there will be a crowd — and, if there is, how many people will be allowed in. Each debate will start at 9 p.m. Eastern time and will run uninterrupted for an hour and a half, according to the Commission on Presidential Debates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Hoffman
title: M.L.B.’s 60-Game Leaderboard, Annotated and Adjusted
description: A pitching triple crown, a potentially cursed batting feat and a 59*-homer season were among the highlights of a season that will stand out like a sore thumb in record books.
content: As soon as a 60-game baseball season was made official, the consternation began over how to handle teams playing 102 fewer games than they would in a normal year. What would the leaderboard look like? What would happen if records were broken? Would they even be able to get through all 60 games?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emile Ducke
title: Glimpses of the Isolated Communities Along a Remote Siberian River
description: Once a vast prison ground for political exiles, the banks of the Ket River are now home to a range of solitary settlements.
content: At the onset of the coronavirus pandemic, with travel restrictions in place worldwide, we launched a new series — The World Through a Lens — in which photojournalists help transport you, virtually, to some of our planet’s most beautiful and intriguing places. This week, Emile Ducke shares a collection of images from Siberia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: Your Best Sandwiches
description: Won’t you tell us what you’re making during the pandemic?
content: I ate ham and cheese sandwiches for two months of lunches, it felt like, until one day I lost the taste for them and had to make a switch. I had a little fist of duck breast left over from when I’d made a couple of them for dinner, cooked slowly on the stovetop under a dusting of five-spice powder. I had some Cheddar, too, and a bag’s end of Swiss chard, bread. Grilled cheese! I made the sandwich out of all that and looked at it a moment before putting it in the pan. Something was missing. I took off the top and dolloped mango chutney all over everything, then reassembled the package and sizzle-sizzle-flipped the thing until everything was crisp and melty.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum
title: Don’t expect the debate moderator Chris Wallace to fact-check on Tuesday.
description: President Trump and Joseph R. Biden Jr. will not be the only ones in the spotlight at their first debate on Tuesday night. Chris Wallace, the Fox News anchor who is moderating, will face intense scrutiny on how he handles the evening, particularly given Mr. Trump’s tendency to hurl false and baseless claims at his opponents.
content: President Trump and Joseph R. Biden Jr. will not be the only ones in the spotlight at their first debate on Tuesday night. Chris Wallace, the Fox News anchor who is moderating, will face intense scrutiny on how he handles the evening, particularly given Mr. Trump’s tendency to hurl false and baseless claims at his opponents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: After a Halt, Then a Sprint, the Cardinals Land in the Playoffs Again
description: After a Covid-19 outbreak, the Cardinals crammed 53 games into the season’s final 44 days. On Sunday, they emerged from a chaotic National League field with a postseason spot.
content: For more than two weeks of the strangest season in major league history, the St. Louis Cardinals disappeared. The birds on the bat flew away for the pandemic, it seemed, and while the rest of the league carried on, the Cardinals wondered if their coronavirus outbreak would cancel their season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nathan Burrow
title: 5 Things to Avoid on Prime Day
description: There will be many traps to fall into, so watch out.
content: After a few months of delays because of the coronavirus pandemic, this year’s Amazon Prime Day is now set for Oct. 13 and 14, just six weeks before Black Friday. The timing will most likely set off a cascade of sales that will last through December, making it even more confusing when you’re trying to determine what’s truly a good value for your money as we all try to shore up our emergency savings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: In Milan, Fashion Tries to Go Back to Normal. What Does That Even Mean?
description: Some unconventional ideas from Moschino and Marni, plus real catwalks with real models at Valentino and Versace. And an octopus guest star.
content: In 1975 Valentino Garavani, then the most feted couturier in Rome, moved his ready-to-wear show from Italy to Paris, the better to underscore his position as an equal of fashion’s luminaries rather than a lord of the outer regions.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How Much Did Trump Win by Losing?
description: A major investigation into President Trump’s finances shows that his businesses reported huge losses. That may have been part of the plan.
content: Check out highlights from Elon Musk’s appearance on Sway, the Times Opinion podcast hosted by Kara Swisher. And read on for a scoop on Jessica Alba’s Honest Company exploring a sale. (Want this in your inbox each morning? Sign up here.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel and Isabella Grullón Paz
title: Supreme Court Vacancy Hasn’t Boosted Trump in Pennsylvania, Poll Shows
description: President Trump had counted on his court nomination over the weekend to shift the election dynamic away from his handling of the coronavirus pandemic. But it has not reset the race in the key battleground state.
content: President Trump’s aggressive drive to add a conservative justice to the Supreme Court before Election Day has not helped him in Pennsylvania, a state crucial to his re-election, where more voters prefer Joseph R. Biden Jr. to fill the vacant seat, according to a poll by New York Times and Siena College released on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher and Katie Glueck
title: How Biden is preparing for the biggest debate of his life.
description: The first debate between Joseph R. Biden Jr. and President Trump on Tuesday represents one of the president’s last, best chances to move a race that polls show him losing. There are risks for Mr. Biden, too.
content: Joseph R. Biden Jr. was frustrated as he tried last year to prepare for an unwieldy debate season that stuffed as many as 11 other Democratic rivals onto a single stage. At some mock sessions, he was flanked by “Elizabeth Warren,” played by Jennifer Granholm, the former governor of Michigan, and “Bernie Sanders,” portrayed by Bob Bauer, the former White House counsel, as they peppered him with progressive lines of attack.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard C. Paddock and Saw Nang
title: Myanmar’s virus restrictions keep journalists at home.
description: The strict stay-at-home order issued by Myanmar last week for its largest city, Yangon, barred residents from traveling from any of its 44 townships to another. There are some exceptions, such as for police officers, emergency workers and doctors.
content: The strict stay-at-home order issued by Myanmar last week for its largest city, Yangon, barred residents from traveling from any of its 44 townships to another. There are some exceptions, such as for police officers, emergency workers and doctors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Satariano
title: Uber Can Continue Operating in London, Judge Rules
description: After a battle with transportation regulators, the ride-hailing firm was granted an 18-month license.
content: LONDON — Uber scored an important victory on Monday when a judge restored the company’s transportation license in London, one of its most important global markets, where regulators had threatened to ban its cars from the road over safety concerns.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A complete guide to how to vote, by mail or in person, early or on Election Day.
description: Many voting rules have changed this year because of the pandemic, making it harder than usual to figure out how to cast your ballot. So we did the work for you, in hopes of helping make sure your vote is counted.
content: Many voting rules have changed this year because of the pandemic, making it harder than usual to figure out how to cast your ballot. So we did the work for you, in hopes of helping make sure your vote is counted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nagourney
title: The velvet shiv vs. the reality TV host: Biden and Trump in the debates.
description: For both President Trump and Joseph R. Biden Jr., the three presidential debates may well be the most critical moments of a fall campaign that is being carried out without the typical dawn-to-dusk days of rallies, local television appearances and talking to voters. Millions of Americans will set aside time in the midst of a pandemic to judge Mr. Trump and Mr. Biden side by side in the unfiltered forum of the two men on a stage.
content: For both President Trump and Joseph R. Biden Jr., the three presidential debates may well be the most critical moments of a fall campaign that is being carried out without the typical dawn-to-dusk days of rallies, local television appearances and talking to voters. Millions of Americans will set aside time in the midst of a pandemic to judge Mr. Trump and Mr. Biden side by side in the unfiltered forum of the two men on a stage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Darnold Throws Three Interceptions in Blowout Loss
description: The Colts returned two of Sam Darnold’s turnovers for touchdowns as the Jets fell to 0-3 for the second consecutive year under Coach Adam Gase.
content: INDIANAPOLIS — Xavier Rhodes delivered the first punch for the Indianapolis Colts on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Martin
title: How I Cover a Debate
description: This time, the setting is different (my couch). But the approach is the same (I get lots of help).
content: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher and Katie Glueck
title: How Joe Biden Is Preparing for the Biggest Debate of His Life
description: The first debate between Joseph R. Biden Jr. and President Trump on Tuesday represents one of the president’s last, best chances to move a race that polls show him losing. There are risks for Mr. Biden, too.
content: [Follow our live updates on Trump vs Biden in the 2020 Election.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Porter
title: Trump, Biden and ‘Made in U.S.A.’: Same Refrain, Varying Notes
description: Joe Biden’s economic proposals show how the president has shifted the playing field toward protectionism. But there may be fewer jobs to lose, or regain.
content: In July, former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. presented an economic strategy to “rebuild domestic manufacturing capacity,” restoring local supply chains from semiconductors to pharmaceuticals. In September he added a tax penalty to the plan, aimed at companies that move jobs to other countries, alongside a tax credit for businesses that bring them home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Blake Gopnik
title: Early Works by Edward Hopper Found to be Copies of Other Artists
description: A grad student’s discovery “cuts straight through the widely held perception of Hopper as an American original,” without a debt to others, a Whitney curator said.
content: Most grad students in art history dream of discovering an unknown work by whatever great artist they are studying. Louis Shadwick has achieved just the opposite: In researching his doctorate on Edward Hopper, for the storied Courtauld Institute in London, Mr. Shadwick has discovered that three of the great American’s earliest oil paintings, from the 1890s, can only barely count as his original images. Two are copies of paintings Mr. Shadwick found reproduced in a magazine for amateur artists published in the years before Hopper’s paintings. The reproductions even came with detailed instructions for making the copies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Takenaga and Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: Millions of children in the developing world are being forced to leave school and go to work.
content: In just 10 months, the coronavirus has killed nearly one million people around the world. At least 3,000 new deaths have been reported every day since July. And that’s just the official count, which far understates the true tally.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Paton, Vanessa Friedman and Constant Méheut
title: Former Fashion Models Accuse Top Agent of Rape and Sexual Assault
description: Prosecutors in Paris are reviewing a complaint containing claims against Gérald Marie, former European chief of Elite Model Management, dating back decades.
content: The former head of one of the world’s biggest modeling agencies is facing a legal investigation in France, after four women reported claims of rape and sexual assault dating back to the 1980s and 1990s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Angelo
title: ‘I Love New York’ Is More Than a Motto
description: As retail chains abandon Manhattan, New Yorkers can rebuild a city that is more hospitable to its small businesses.
content: When I founded Michael Angelo’s Wonderland Beauty Parlor in the meatpacking district 15 years ago, I never imagined I would one day have to downsize and relocate to survive rising rents, only to have to then shut down for months. Nor could I conceive of having to choose between paying the rent on my apartment, paying the lease on the salon or putting food on the table.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raphael Minder
title: Spanish Court Upholds Ban on Catalan Leader
description: The decision barring the separatist president of Catalonia’s regional government, Quim Torra, from holding public office confirms a ruling in December and threatens to reignite unrest.
content: MADRID — The Supreme Court of Spain on Monday upheld a ruling barring the separatist leader of Catalonia from public office, a decision that could renew tensions in the restive northeastern region.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Gendler
title: 2020 French Open: What to Watch on Monday
description: Serena Williams sets off on her quest for a 24th Grand Slam title and Dominic Thiem looks to capitalize on his momentum after winning the United States Open.
content: How to watch: From 3 a.m. Eastern to noon on Tennis Channel, and from noon to 3 p.m. on NBC; streaming on Tennis Channel and NBCSN apps.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nikil Saval
title: Design for the Future When the Future Is Bleak
description: Amid pandemics and environmental disasters, designers and architects have been forced to imagine a world in which the only way to move forward is to look back.
content: AT ITS CORE, design is an inherently futurist medium. In the 1960s, as the writer Maggie Gram has noted, key figures in the Modern design movement often used the word “design” indistinguishably from the word “planning.” This isn’t surprising: Design, like planning, was the profession most concerned with the future. Today is not so different, but what we mean by “the future,” a utopian ideal throughout much of the 20th century, is now undeniably much darker as we progress further into the 21st. To look ahead at what role design will play on an increasingly troubled planet takes us back to the fundamental polysemy behind the word itself. At various times it has encompassed drawing and architecture, products and graphics — in fact, everything short of the creation of the world itself (and, in the risible concept of “intelligent design,” sometimes that, too). Once industrial design became a profession in the early 20th century, the promiscuity of its aims and undefined nature of its objectives meant that designers felt they could do very nearly anything. In its most heroic phase, the mid-20th century, industrial designers gave themselves over to pronouncements that suggested they alone held the key to this savage parade. “What are the boundaries of design?” was the question posed in 1969 to Charles Eames, who, with his partner, Ray, designed chairs, toys, housing, films, exhibitions and, to a certain extent, the very nature of communication. Eames responded, “What are the boundaries of problems?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker and Michael D. Shear
title: Trump Deflects Questions About Taxes, but First Debate Has a New Issue
description: While the president’s Republican allies generally kept their silence, Democrats pounced and former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., the party’s presidential candidate, posted a video noting that the president paid less in income taxes than everyday Americans.
content: WASHINGTON — The disclosure that President Trump paid little or no federal income taxes for years, including while in the White House, convulsed the presidential campaign on Monday with only five weeks to go and immediately scrambled the equation and stakes of the first debate to be held on Tuesday night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany Hsu
title: ‘Fox & Friends,’ With Donald Trump Jr., Tries to Dismiss Times Tax Article
description: The Fox News morning show, a reliable forum for the president and his defenders, served up criticism of the report and attacks on Joseph R. Biden Jr.
content: The popular Fox News morning show “Fox & Friends” was a TV home for Donald J. Trump long before he became president. In 2011, Mr. Trump had a regular Monday slot on the program, where he bonded with the hosts by hurling invective at President Barack Obama and promoting the false theory that Mr. Obama was not born in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Revelations About Donald Trump’s Taxes
description: Readers react to The Times’s investigation of the president’s finances.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Trump’s Tax Returns, Coronavirus Deaths, Charlie Hebdo: Your Monday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
